[b]7.0/10.0[/b]

This game is not just a(nother) bad indie attempt on a remake, but an actually and authentic remake on a early 90's platformer classic.
At first glance the game resemble Duke Nukem 1, and do have some similarities.
If you are at my age (late-20'ies or older), you probably remember platformers like Duke Nukem 1, Commander Keen and such. And if you enjoy these games, you will probably enjoy this too. This game is 100 % true to the original platformers from the early 90's in every way (and only obtain 3 MB).
The game however, is quite short. You will probably complete all 4 episodes in 2-4 hours, depending on how much exploring after secrets, and hunt for a 100 % collect you are doing.

Younger gamers from a later generation than I am, will probably not enjoy this game that much, since much of the joy (for me) is the nostalgic feeling. And games from this era just have an other playstile than modern games, primaly due to the limited technological possibilities.

But as mentioned above, if you are looking for a cheap, nostalgic experience, grab MURI.

37941709.review:
An interesting attempt at a DOS style game that succeeds in it's aim of being a DOS game while not accomplishing much else. I played this offline while travelling and while it was ultimately a harmless experience, it failed to do anything that hasn't been done better in the past. That, of course, is the challenge of making a faithful recreation; where do you innovate without losing the faithfulness? 

I'm recommending MURI simply because it succeeds in doing exactly what it sets out to, for better or worse. The music is nostalgically clunky, the combat stilted yet precise, and the story almost non-existant. The limited color pallete is used exceptionally well, and even though the graphics are simple, even by DOS standards, it succeeded in keeping me visually engaged.

If you're hunting for this particular style of game, it will scratch your itch. While not for everyone, MURI is respectable if a bit too faithful for it's own good. Definitely worth a shot on sale to see if you like it or not.

35758845.review:
I grew up on DOS games and I played a good few shareware games like the original Duke Nukem. 

Story:

In the future, Mars has been colonized but after a powerful armor suit, the factions of Earth send their robot armies to destroy it. After Mars disappears, Adwoa, one of the suits creators,  wakes up and soon discover whats going on.

I don’t really have much to say about this story other than it’s differently one of the more darker story this company has come up with with the world in ruins. I do think it a decent story of someone finding her a way to redeem herself. 

Gameplay:

Straight forward run and shoot gameplay. Just jump and shoot and it works well.  I never figured out how to switch weapons but there a good to use with my favourites being rapid fire and the homing fire blast. Enemies are colour coded from green to grey so you know how dangerous they are. They even have a flash effect when they’re about to attack so you have time to dodge.

The levels and episodes are both pretty short which is good cause this game has no save system. The bosses are decent with a good but silly final boss but one thing I found odd is that mini bosses appear in the last level before a main boss. There aren’t too hard and you usually get a reward for beating them, it just seems like on odd place to put a mini boss.

Presentation:

The first Duke Nukem game was my main thought when I seen this art style. Everything has that early DOS feel with it’s backgrounds, pictures and sound effects. While I don’t mind the enemy design and even like some of them like those giant squares, I would say they seem a bit generic.

While I do like the  DOS sound effects, I’m disappointed that there’s no music besides the main menu. Yes the original Duke Nukem didn’t have music but I think you could’ve gotten away with it with modern technology.

Verdict:

An authentic DOS experience and if you like the demo, give the full game a try.

8/10

30361757.review:
MURI Review - Raymond KT

This old-style game has you trying to find out why Mars has disappeared, and as you run and gun across the four episodes you discover the answers via cut scenes.As a platform/shooter (with its slower pace) it is like playing the DOS games of old and with about 2 hours worth of play, the game is a short one, but it has lots of secret areas to be found. The lack of a save point can be annoying to some modern players and the game could of benefited with some music to add a little more atmosphere, but overall this is a little great game

So you grew up in the '90s, right? Played a lot of Commander Keen, Biomenace, Duke Nukem (the first two) and all sorts of other two-dimensional platformers? Or at least you're hip and nerdy enough to honestly appreciate those kind of games?

Well, here's your chance to relive that particular place in time and space with a new adventure! Play MURI for ten seconds and you'll be thrown back immediately (actually you don't even need those ten seconds - just look at the intro screen and listen to the theme music), and ever now and then you get surprised by some more modern contraptions. The level design is fun and does the one thing right that so many games do wrong nowadays: you can fully backtrack every part of the level at your own pace and leisure to get all those hidden secrets and goodies. Yet the enemies are the most interesting part of this short little hommage to the oldschool platforming era. They're quite original in design and behaviour and they fit the weird SciFi storyline perfectly imho. Get this game (especially when it's on sale, it can get as low as €0.39) and enjoy your one or two hours of well executed retro fun. I know for sure I did.

28758069.review:
Really slick throwback to classic DOS run 'n guns like Duke Nukem and Commander Keen. Nice that the dev tried to remain authentic to MURI's forerunners, though the 'authentic' 16 fps setting ended up giving me motion sickness about an episode in. Had to change it to smooth fps to resume comfortable play.

Setting up an Xbox 360 controller was really easy and the controls respond well. MURI doesn't like alt-tabbing out of full screen, so the few times I did, I needed to quit the episode to re-configure Jump to A.

Biggest drawbacks? The two problems mentioned above, plus NO MUSIC. For what it's worth, the game plays really well to the classic Mega Man soundtracks.

Only took me 90 minutes to beat on Normal, even with restarting Episode 2 twice after alt-tab shenanigans. But the multiple difficulties and high score hunting give MURI good replay value.

Overall? A good game, especially for its price.

24295882.review:
[h1]A faithful callback to Keen 1 or Nukem 1[/h1]

Muri is Japanese for "impossible". It's also the name of the highest difficulty setting in the game. But it's not one of those ultra-hard platformers. Instead, it's just a small and well made package.
There are 4 episodes of 5 levels each. I couldn't tell you the story because I skipped through it.

[b]What I enjoyed[/b]
[list]
[*]Non-linear levels that encourage exploring everywhere for pickups and secrets.
[*]Simple, useful weapon upgrades.
[*]Good difficulty curve.
[*]The player character is a reluctant middle-aged, slightly overweight woman in a power suit. Sure, why not?
[*]Boss battles that aren't annoying.
[*]EGA look with some modern options for convenience. Make sure to set for graphics upscaling and smooth 32-bit scrolling.
[*]Oooh it does this thing where if you're facing left/right and you shoot in that direction and while shooting you move in the other direction, you walk backwards while maintaining your aim. Very handy!
[/list]
[b]What I didn't like[/b]
[list]
[*]My biggest gripe is not being able to change keyboard controls. It comes with several schemes, but none suit me.
[*]Can't save. You can select which episode to play, but you'll have to repeat the levels if you'd previously stopped in the middle of it. (just like in those old games!)
[*]Jumping feels weird, like a mix of jumping and jetpacking. You get used to it. (just like in those old games!)
[/list]
It's nice when a game is content with being good.

23459306.review:
On the surface it's just a DOS-era throwback indie game, and at first indeed it seems pretty simple with not much to it; EGA-inspired graphcis, no music save for a simple title screen theme, 80s standard ancient soundcard-style crude sound effects, and unless you manually choose 32-bit smooth scrolling (which I would highly recommend for all but the most hardcore DOS nostalgia hounds), very period-accurate low-framerate stuttery gameplay.

However, look past that (or play for just a little while) and you'll find quite a hidden gem.  The long and short of it is that MURI is FUN.   The gameplay may seem a bit archaic to modern players -- limited ammo for all but your default pea shooter (unless you can collect enough of a certain type before it runs out, but that's easier said than done), somewhat mazelike stages with forcefields you have to unlock, freeform level design with many alternate routes and hidden secrets, a [B]SCORE[/B] system for goodness' sake?!  But after a few minutes of play you'll find yourself mowing through surprisingly quickly with very solid controls, an extremely powerful standard jump that makes exploring fun and easy, lots of powerful weapons you can use as often as you'd like and will almost definitely never completely run out of them all, balanced and fun enemies to face that can be challenging but aren't too tough to handle on a first run, cool bosses... it hits all the marks for a good old fashioned shooter/platformer.

So, set it to smooth scrolling, turn on some classic video game tunes of your choice and zip through the four episodes in an hour or two.  You won't regret it.

22747428.review:
MURI is remarkably better than I expected. I grew up on Commander Keen and Duke Nukem 1&2, but I often don't like hardcore retro throwbacks (I Wanna Be The Guy). Muri manages to combine an interesting and concisely told story with the simple and challenging gameplay of yore. 

The multiple difficulty levels allow you to waltz through the game or punish yourself. I played on Normal and had several harrowing moments and deaths I looked forward to avenging. Generally, I stopped playing for the day when I died, but kept coming back. It's easy to get into a play session, but it only saves when you unlock a new chapter. This unlock system and the fun-but-challenging difficulty combined with plentify pickups in the levels made it always seem like success was only just out of reach and I wasn't cursing the game in frustration.

The bosses are fun. The sessions are short. The jumping is high. The secrets are everywhere.

On the downside, Muri doesn't work at all with my wired Xbox 360 controller. I've setup Joy2Key to play it and that worked well, but shouldn't be necessary for a "Partial Controller Support" game.

22721211.review:
MURI feels like a game designed with a purpose, and it meets that purpose well. It duplicates the appearance and structure of an EGA-era DOS platformer, and feels very authentic to that. It even has an option to scroll tile-by-tile as those games often did to compensate for the underpowered PC graphics hardware of the day. 

The game consists of twenty levels divided into four episodes. Much like the games it follows, you do lose all your weapons and powerups after each, but the game is designed for this; boss fights give you massive arsenal upgrades and the first level always gives you a few extra guns if you're careful with your special ammunition.

The game's challenge level is fairly even, with a gentle upward slope as you progress. Though the game's final chapters do ramp up the enemy and bullet density, there aren't any egregious 'gotcha' spots, at least on Normal difficulty that I played.

Overall it's an average game, but one worth playing if you enjoy the EGA aesthetic. If you're a fan of Duke Nukem 1 and 2, or Commander Keen, grab this.

20740983.review:
Fun if you enjoy challenging, nostalgic games. 
With all the megaman, sonic, and mario homage games out there these days it snice to play something that references back to the games *I* played in my childhood: DOS platformers. You could list out dozens of classic DOS games that Muri is like but it bares the strongest resembalence to the original Duke Nukum even to the point of having nearly identical assets at times.

Where Muri fails at its emulaiton of Duke is its lack of puzzles to progress, most levels can just be run through without fighting enemies (if you dodge their attacks) and rarely do you ever encounter anything more than a few tricky platforming sections. The Challenge of Muri comes from its unforgiving combat and sheer number of enemies. I don't particularly care for that aspect of the game so I played on an easier difficulty and just enjoyed the nostalgic gameplay. 

Where Muri wins majorly is its secrets, it has TONS of hidden areas and secret items throughout the levels which  allow you access to special weapons at the boss fights. If you enjoy finding secrets and racking up a  high score this  is the game for you.

[u]Амелия Бренд[/u]: [i]Может быть, любовь - это нечто большее, что мы не в силах... пока осознать? Что ни говори, а за детьми всегда нужен глаз да глаз. Иначе родителей ждёт в лучшем случае [url=www.imdb.com/title/tt0467406/]ранняя беременность у любимого чада[/url], а в худшем - [url=ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Массовое_убийство_в_школе_«Колумбайн»]трагедия, разыгравшейся в школе "Колумбайн"[/url]. В частности, безответственность создателей суперкостюма [i]MURI[/i], попавшего в руки их юного отпрыска [i]Коджо[/i], обернулась для последнего коматозным состоянием¹, исчезновением [i]Марса[/i] и гибелью людской цивилизации... Вы точно уверены, что вину за воспитание наших детей справедливо перекладывать исключительно на плечи педагогов?

[u][b]Zeitgeist[/b][/u]
S for stylization. Шведский коллектив [b]Ludosity[/b] (в котором трудится известный в узких кругах разработчик [url=www.remar.se/daniel/games.php]Дониель Ремар[/url]) не просто вдохновлялся ностальгией, но сотворил игру, практически во всём отвечающую лекалам ранних 90-х. А значит, если [b]indie-сцена[/b] прежде всего привлекает читателя нестандартными геймдизайнерскими решениями (читай - головоломками), то данную аркадную "пострелушку" он может спокойно пропускать.

Её визуальное оформление создано для тех, кто по сей день грезит [b]DOS[/b], [b]ZX Spectrum[/b] и [b]Apple //[/b], а практически полное отсутствие музыки и характерные звуковые эффекты идеально подчёркивают лаконичность игрового дизайна. Однако это отнюдь не комплимент, а лишь сухая констатация факта. Да, постапокалиптические приключения [i]Адвоа[/i] - упитанной матери двоих детей в костюмчике à la [url=www.imdb.com/title/tt0088863/]"Bubblegum Crisis"[/url] (уместное сравнение, если учесть, что её основным противником выступает [i]армия роботов[/i]), - получились в целом на голову выше посредственной [url=store.steampowered.com/app/45730/]"Dark Void Zero"[/url], но по разнообразию игровых ситуаций и красочности та самая классика легко даст новоделу фору. Увы, стрельба (в наличии четыре вида оружия, одно из которых модифицируется, а также проверенный временем итальянский рукопашный приём в виде прыжка на голову) в двух направлениях, сбор предметов, поиск секретов и решение банальных головоломок, несмотря на удобное управление, режим [i]TURBO[/i] и хороший баланс, едва ли заинтересуют ветеранов [url=www.dosgamesarchive.com/download/duke-nukem/]"Duke Nukem"[/url], [url=www.gog.com/game/dangerous_dave_pack]"Dangerous Dave in the Haunted Mansion"[/url] и [url=ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contra]"Contra"[/url]. Однако...

В отличии от предшественников, свобода творчества шведов выпала на [url=www.imdb.com/title/tt0112159/]"постъевангелионовскую[/url] эпоху" и им уже ничто не мешало разыграть сюжетную карту в лучших традициях японских фантастических мультсериалов. А поскольку секрет успеха наших заморских соседей до неприличия прост - нагнать на историю туману в лице сюжетных хитросплетений, интригующих тайных организаций, недосказанности и откровенной мистики ради создания эмоционального ореола вокруг неоднозначных персонажей, - то научной фантастики от истории с экспериментальными [i]костюмами MURI[/i] (одни из которых уничтожают планеты, в то время как другие могут быть разрушены охранными дронами) и [i]марсианскими призраками[/i] ждать, к сожалению, не стоит.

Всех остальных, несмотря на минимализм художественных средств, канва о фатальных злоключениях семьи [i]Адвоа[/i] не оставит равнодушными. Пробуждение, конфликт с дочерью, долгожданная встреча с сыном, искупление перед человечеством и романтический катарсис в открытом финале. [b]Key[/b] и [b]ORiGO GAMES[/b] определённо есть чему учиться у европейских коллег.

В заключение, ваш покорный слуга рекомендует приготовить геймпад и дождаться скидок, а также напоминает о необходимости вовремя решать конфликты взаимопонимания в семье и не спускать подобные проблемы на тормозах.

Time to put that 360 controller away bust out the old Gravis Gamepad, because this game does retro right.
16 frames a second, EGA graphics, almost PC speaker audio--the only things missing are dos4gw, autoexec.bat, and spending 20 minutes trying to figure out your DMA/IRQ settings while the audio setup crashes when you get it wrong.
The only, ONLY knock I will have against it is the difficulty. Even on max, it's not very hard.

--I'm going to go on a very shaky limb and say it is more enjoyable than a lot of the games it is trying to replicate, though--

Oh, and the whole game fits on three 3 1/4" floppies.

17805712.review:
Solid gameplay, fluent controls and charming throwback graphics make for an enjoyable experience which MURI provides. 

The game is extremely short; I completed my first playthrough in roughly an hour, however, if you were to go around collecting all the pick-ups and finding all the secrets, you would probably get another hour or so at the very least. I expect replay value to be somewhat low overall.

There's a decent variety of enemies you encounter and slay along the way and the boss fights, while not particularly challenging or extraordinary, are still frantic and fun to blast through. There is also a variety of weapon upgrades and power-ups you may encounter, ranging from rapid-fire to lazer blasts that ricochet off the walls.

The levels are not linear however they are still easy to navigate through and they're designed quite well, though they all kind of feel the same. But you shouldn't ever need to worry about getting lost.

All in all, MURI is a solid action platformer that truly reminds us of the old days of gaming and deserves at least one playthrough; for four bucks, it's worth it.

This is a love letter to the DOS Era of PC gaming. 
Mostly Apogee platformers Era (Duke Nukem 1, Cosmo's Cosmic Adventure, Secret Agent, Crystal Caves)

* 16 EGA-like colors
* PC-Speaker-like sounds and music.
* One button for jump, and one for shooting.

The game is pretty short, and very easy on normal difficulty, so I recommend higher difficulty levels for old school gamers.

17257173.review: If you like Duke Nukem 1 then you like this too.

17241482.review:
Muri is a charming homage to early DOS era platforming - if you have fond memories of the gameplay found in early Commander Keen or Duke Nukem games, you'll feel right at home here. Every part of this game's aesthetic feels extremely consistent with the style they're trying to emulate, but the story is a bit complex and convoluted. Perhaps credit is deserved for trying to explore dramatic themes far beyond the scope of the gameplay, but it just felt a bit out of place - simpler character motivations would have felt more authentic to early DOS experiences.

I'm not really the sort of person who can ignore story elements, even in a game as purposefully simple as this, but Muri makes me wish I was. It has a wonderful sense of feedback for every control input, and feels like an incredibly honest love letter to a fascinating era of gaming history. Still strongly recommended.

17104668.review:
A short action platformer based on MS-DOS nostalgia.
The levels and mechanics are very carefully made, as it's to be expected from the creator.
There's lots of side paths and hidden powerups. This can make exploration very fun, but if you don't care about looking for them, you'll be underwhelmed.
The game evokes the atmosphere of the DOS era very well, and is very faithful to the limitations of the platform. Fortunately you can disable the 16fps lock to make it easier on the eyes.

The story is confusing, but imo fascinating.

15014041.review:
MURI is a great retro platformer game, very faithful to the PC games from early 90s or 80s.

The graphics are well drawn and use a fairly restricted color palette, simulating the early DOS games with EGA graphics card. The sound also simulates what early games sounded on the built-in PC speaker (there was no sound card in the early days).

The levels are also very well designed and have some secrets, although they are not too difficult to find if you spend some time exploring all areas. The secrets usually have some hints indicating there is a hidden passage or there is some puzzle-ish element (such as destroying some blocks). That way, they never feel "cheap" nor frustrating. In fact, they are quite straightforward.

Joystick is supported, but I had trouble configuring the D-pad in-game. Instead, I just used Xpadder (or Joy2Key) to emulate keypresses.

The gameplay itself has a brilliant touch: you can either play in 16fps, which really simulates the movement of early PC games such as "Duke Nukum" (the first Duke Nukem game). Alternatively, you can also play the game with smooth movement in 32fps, which feels more responsive and more modern. Either way, the game plays very well, the controls are very responsive, and the game feels balanced.

14184126.review:
MURI is a side-scrolling action platformer, and a clear throwback to the 8-bit era! Instead of NES, though, this one tributes the DOS-side, citing  Duke Nukum as the biggest influence.

While the game does very little to innovate, it's a very accessible game, especially for people unfamiliar with the difficulty of older games. If you are looking for that challenge, however, there are modes to make that happen!

It's a very [i]by the book[/i] game, in my opinion, but I think it's well done.


[b][u]Presentation[/u][/b] 
I'm not sure if it's worth this, but the game [b]looks[/b] like it's from the 80s, as intended! Low-res, limited color-scheme, 16fps -- it's all there! (Although there's a 32fps version, which feels much better to play)
What you see in the screenshots is what you get. It seems very faithful to the era it's celebrating.
It also features color-coded enemies, each color representing a difficulty-tier.
Everything is well delineated, and there's never any confusion between what's an enemy, background and foreground.

The [b]sound-effects[/b] follow the same route. If you like playing your own music while playing game, those can certainly be very annoying, but you should know what you're getting into. 
There's one big issue, though, in the fact that there's no [b]music[/b]! I'm not familiar with the DOS era, so I'm not sure if it was common practice for games not to have music. In NES games, though, music was one of its strong points! And it's very unfortunate that MURI does not have any. There's a very short and looping track in the menu, but on its own, it does nothing to standout.

You could always listen to a podcast or something while playing it, though, without hurting the experience.

[b][u]Struture[/u][/b]
There are 4 [b]episodes[/b] in MURI. Each episode is self-contained, and has 5 stages, one of which is a boss fight. 
There are [b]no saves[/b], as expected. However, every difficulty mode and episode is unlocked from the start. Your only worry is to play one episode at once.
You can probably be done with the episodes in 20 minutes, even less if you don't bother with exploration.

There are 4 (acceptable) difficulties available - Easy, Normal, Hard and MURI. I can't say for sure if the enemies actually change between these modes, but what I can say, is that they change the Health and Lives Pick-ups in the levels, depending on the chosen difficulty. Each of them has a Score Multiplier associated with it.

I've played it on [b]Normal[/b], and then gave it a spin on [b]MURI[/b], just to see how it was. Normal mode should cause major problems to anyone. If you take the time to explore, you'll have more than enough lives and health pick-ups to carry you through. I didn't get any game-over in this mode. Hard will most likely be the most suitable for any more or less experienced player.
MURI, on the other hand, is more of a real challenge! There are not health pick ups nor lives anywhere. You'll have 3 lives for each episode, and that's it. This was certainly not the kind of experience I was looking for when I started playing MURI, but it's good to know it's there! (I have yet to play Volgarr the Viking)
Your health is restored between each stage, in all modes, which is very handy! It's also a small reward on the harder modes, to be able to take damage in moderation without it being an issue.


On every stage there are tons of secrets, in the form of fake and destroyable walls, hidden platforms, etc. for you to uncover, getting score pick-ups and lives as well as ammunition for the more powerful weapons. Your score is increased by picking things up and killing enemies -- a very welcome aspect is how the game tells you when you reach 100% Score for that specific stage! I think it's very fair. It doesn't tell you too much, but you can be sure to leave the stage without leaving anything behind, if you so want.

There are also hidden Cells. These will unlock the more powerful weapons for the Boss stage, but are also more challenging to get.

If you lose all of your lives, you'll get a game over screen, and "back to the menu with you"! Again, it should not be a problem in Normal Mode, at least.


[b][u]Mechanics & Level Design[/u][/b]
I've covered part of this on the previous section. No worries, there's still a bit to talk about.

I've mentioned several weapons. These include your basic, infinite, slow shot. Then, there's Rapid Shot, MKV (Scatter gun), Laser gun, Explosive-shot gun, and a Crazy Barrage of Large Bouncy Shots gun. You'll be able to get ammo hidden through the stages. You always keep what you collect when you finish a stage -- except, of course, between episodes -- so exploration is highly encouraged.
Your active weapon is [i]always[/i] the most powerful one for which you have ammo. I dislike this quite a lot. I don't see a reason for not allowing the player to switch between weapons, but I couldn't find one. This leads to you wasting very valuable ammo on the weakest enemies, and then having an hard time with the tougher ones -- note that this only made a difference in MURI mode, but still.


[b][i]How the level-design encourages exploration[/i][/b] 
First off, the game constantly teases you by showing you pick-ups inside the walls. You know you [i]can[/i] get there; all that's left is figuring out how!
The game doesn't try to hide many things. It's mostly very fair in that regard, as it gives you glimpses of possible secrets and fake walls every time.
Another way that I highly respect is that they [b]never[/b] close a door behind you -- figuratively speaking.
There are no pits from which you can't get back, doors that close or anything of the sort. If you've left something behind, as long as you don't leave the stage, you can always go back to find it. This also goes hand in hand with the fact that they tell you when you reach 100% score. If they didn't tell you when you're near the exit, you've missed something -- Feel free to go back and explore some more!

[b][i]Enemy Variety and Difficulty[/i][/b]
There are lots of different enemies, each with their movement pattern, health, directional shots, etc. For its low length and amount of episodes, Muri compensates with the very varied enemies and levels in general. It'll never feel repetitive during the first playthrough! And if you're actively looking for this kind of game, I'm sure you can play through it at least twice without it feeling boring at all.
For each type of enemy, there are also different tiers, identified by their color. Green are the easiest, then Blue, Red and Grey, with these being the harder.

The enemies are well placed, and the game is never unfair. You can always see shots coming before getting hit. Enemies outside the screen still shoot at you and take damage, so you'll have to be careful.

One of the aspects characteristic of these old games is how methodical they are to play, and MURI is no different. If you rush, you'll probably get hit often, and end up losing a bunch of lives. If you play it slow, and be aware of the enemies' patterns, though, you'll be able to succeed with conviction. 
If you've played NES or DOS games, you'll know whether this is for you.


The Boss Fights were also pretty fun, with multiple phases, as is classic. They also change depending on the difficulty you're playing on, which is always good to see!

[b][i]No saves[/i][/b]
I've seen some people unhappy with the lack of lives. I'd generally agree, especially in the easier difficulties, as it's very frustrating to lose a whole level of progress. 
However, I don't think you have anything to worry about, in this game. MURI mode is there for the more hardcore players. If you're not one of them, exploration will reward you with plenty of lives. It's old-school design, but made more accessible. I do not think it poses an issue.


This one comes from [b]Ludosity[/b], who are yet to disappoint me. Give it a go!

14147106.review:
Designed to look, sound and play like a DOS game, this is a paean to the power of the aesthetic.  It could almost be running via DOSBox, such is the atmosphere of the game. A platform action game at heart with a lot of shooting, this is a fun albeit short-lived experience.  The graphics are suitably EGA like; there is no in-game music and the sound effects are pleasingly simplistic.

Some of the deliberate constraints may annoy those not used to playing old-style games: weapon selection is automatic - the most powerful weapon is always chosen.  The frame rate is choppy, but you can make it smoother in the menu.  There is no map or indicator of where to go next; fortunately the stages are not a sprawling affair - you can get through most levels quickly if you decide to.

There are some concessions which help make it less frustrating for some folk.  There are several small rooms hidden from view, usually with a power-up or scoring items.  You are briefly invincible when hit, enemies' bullets are large and easy to see and you can repeatedly bounce on most enemies to damage them.  There are several difficulty levels and the cut scenes can be skipped.  You have all this fun with no need to add commands like DEVICEHIGH=C:\WINDOWS\EMM386.EXE RAM into your AUTOEXEC.BAT file.

14055148.review:
[b]MURI[/b] taps into a largely untouched nostalgia pocket, that of the DOS-era platformer. The gameplay & presentation feel wonderfully authentic, and the sci-fi theme is especially well executed within the stark EGA palette. MURI's pixel art awesomely captures the style of the time, and the same can be said of the crunchy PC speaker beepboops that may as well be forcing their way out the cracks of an IBM taking up your desk.

More importantly, though, each of MURI's levels are loaded with thoughtfully placed secret areas & collectible doodads, and the whole game features consistently satisfying shooty action platforming that fans of the original two Duke Nukems will feel instantly at home with.

[h1]If you're in the mood for something a lil' old fashioned, [b]MURI is a seriously refreshing & soulful alternative to the droves of pseudo-8-bit retro platformers in rotation.[/b][/h1]

If only Remar Games / Ludosity could chop the game down into a Shareware-style demo sold on a floppy at the dollar store, fanatical levels of period authenticity be damned.

14055096.review:
This action platformer has tight controls, solid action, a fair challenge and rewards exploration with useful power-ups, no filler content anywhere (unlike many AAA titles these days). I was initially thrown off by the very dated graphics (this game was made to look and play like a DOS-era 2D shooter) but as the proverb goes "Do not judge a book by its cover" and for this game "do not judge a game until you've played it". Very pleasantly surprised. There isn't much music but the sound effects fit nicely what tunes there are fit the mood. The difficulty settings actually tweak some bosses to go along with the chosen setting and ensure everyone from the hardcore to the casual players (and the ones in between) can play this game end to end. The story is serviceable if at times bizarre. The levels are designed to be short and each act (which you can choose from when starting a new game) consists of 5 levels so the arcade experience and meaning of losing a life still holds.

TL; DR: Don't let the graphics throw you off, this here is a mighty fine 2D action platformer and shooter that just shows how much solid gameplay mechanics and outright fun trump polygon count any day!

I record this Review as *Thumb Sideways* 


I'm not a Retro Gamer.

If it wasn't for the lack of control-bindings, I'd no doubt be able to play adequately (and more thoroughly enjoy it).
If it wasn't for the lack of being able to choose what sort of ammo/power-up to use when, I'd no doubt play through all the Chapters (no such strategy in a game that somewhat necessitates it in the platforming?).

13768045.review:
MURI is as close as you can get to having a Shovel Knight or Cave Story for DOS platformers. Like the latter two, MURI takes old school aesthetics and mechanics and gives them a modern level of polish and accessibility while still being challenging. It's an excellently executed game from the creator of games like Garden Gnome Carnage and Iji.

Pros:
+ Authentically emulates the sights and sounds of DOS-era platformers.

+ Simple, but slick controls. I always felt like I had my character flawlessly jumping and shooting enemies. Shooting while moonwalking is a welcome addition.

+ Great level design. Each level feels distinct, has multiple pathways and is filled with clever secrets. 

+ Tons upon tons of secrets for each level. MURI encourages exploration and completion for each level, showing when you have achieved 100% for each one. The secrets are well-hidden but gives enough of a hint to uncover them.

+ Fantastic pacing. MURI always knows when and where to throw enemies at you while giving you just the right amount of firepower and health to do so.

+ An interesting attempt at a complex story that juxtaposes well with the era it tries to emulate.

+ A female protagonist who's also a mother. You can never have enough good female leads.

+ Great boss battles. Each one tests the limits of your skills and make excellent climaxes.

+ Great value for about 2 to 3 dollars.

Mixed:

/ Inability to switch between weapons removes some choice, but it also keeps you from hoarding them, forcing you to adapt to any new weapon you get.

/ MURI makes an admirable attempt at a story that juxtaposes well with the DOS aesthetic, but unfortunately it ends up as difficult to follow.

/ The game takes about 2 to 3 hours to finish, but those 2 to 3 hours are so fun that you won't regret enjoying it. 

Cons:
- Lack of 60 FPS. The max you can have is 32, but this doesn't detract from the gameplay at all.
- Somewhat short. It can be finished in about a few hours, but those few hours are very well-spent.
- Deserves a level editor.

Verdict: If you loved DOS games like Duke Nukem, Halloween Harry or Commander Keen, or you just love action platformers, MURI is right up your alley.

13650224.review:
This game is what it claims to be, a retro-styled throwback to DOS platformers, particularly the Duke Nukum line.  However, this game is almost painfully easy, rarely a challenge in it at all.  Nothing to overcome.  Lots of invisible exploration passages, some over-powered weapons, the final chapter even lets you have an unlimited version of the most powerful weapon if you spent some time in the previous levels exploring.  The story is... insane.  Not well thought through.  I'm giving it a 'no', because the game just felt too hollow.  Here, after one and a quarter hours, I have completed the whole thing.  The story wasn't engaging, the gameplay was light, there just isn't enough meat on this bone to make me able to recommend it.

HOWEVER, if you're alright with a platformer on the easy side, with a half-baked story, and just want to kill a few hours, this game is perfect for it.  If they make a sequel, I probably will look into it.  I just hope there's more to it than this one.

Edit: There is also no way to rebind the keyboard controls.  That's inexcusable for a PC game anymore, even one attempting to be a throwback like this.  On top of that, there is a problem where the game does not exit properly.

13524475.review:
Mamy aktualnie mode na retro gry, więc powstają też takie gry jak Muri. Muri ma wyglądać jak gierka z czasów, kiedy to rządził system DOS i nawet dobrze poszło twórcom. W MURI wcielamy się w jednego z ocalałych, który ma specjalną zbroję i musimy uratować ziemię przed najeźdźcami, postać widzimy z boku oraz pomoże nam 6 broni, które zbieramy po drodze, które się wyróżnia na swój sposób. Grafika jest całkiem przyjemna, jak na próbe cofnięcia gry w czasie do czasów DOS-a. Muzyka w sumie jest tylko jedna i jest tylko w menu i napisach końcowych, ale pasuje do gry. Fabuła jak na taką małą gierke to może być. Wrogowie, jak i ich zróżnicowanie jest bardzo dobre. Poziom trudności jest dosyć wysoki, a grałem na Normalu. Poziomów jest w sumie 20, mamy 4 rozdziały po 5 plansz, gdzie w ostatnich poziomach w danym rozdziale walczymy z Bossem, którego pokonuje się na swój sposób. Jak chodzi wam tylko o przejście gry to gra zajmie wam godzinę na normalu razem ze znalezieniem wszystkich ukrytych pomieszczeń i bonusów. O optymalizacji w takiej grze nie ma co mówić, bo taka gra jak MURI czy inne gry w stylu retro nie mają problemów z optymalizacją i błędami. Przejde do plusów i minusów:
+Nie rażąca grafika
+Muzyka, mimo że jedynie jest menu i na napisach końcowych, pozwala poczuć klimat gry
+Gameplay jest całkiem dobry
+Fabuła może być
+Gra pójdzie raczej na każdym kompie, dzięki bardzo małych wymaganiach i mikrorozmiarom(na tosterze nie sprawdzałem, ale pewnie też pójdzie :D)
+Różnorodni wrogowie
+Ukryte pomieszczenia i bonusy
+Niedługa, ale zawsze mozna pograć na wyższych poziomach trudności
+Przejście gry jest wyzwaniem, bo łatwo stracić życie czasem
+Karty Steam, które są nieco warte
Moja ocena to 10/10, nie zauważyłem żadnych wad, a pograć w to może każdym na jakimkolwiek komputerze czy laptopie, twórcy postarali się, żeby każdy mógł w to zagrać i jak najbardziej polecam pograć w tą gierke, jeśli lubicie stare dobre gry.

13109864.review:
If you want a pretty solid recreation on what classic DOS-based platformers were like back in the day, but don't want to go through the hassle of getting those set up, or want something that's maybe a little more concise and well put together, look no further than MURI.  This is a game that emulates the style almost perfectly, right down to score collectibles, stage layouts, and even an optional 16 frames per-second gameplay mode. It's a simple little run and gunner with 20 stages that you'll probably end up blasting through in a relatively short amount of time (since the stages are in no way as labyrinthine or exhausting as some of those older games could get), but you'll either appreciate the call back to those gems of the past or understand the earlier days of PC gaming just a bit more.  

If the game does have one standout feature, it's that its story, simple as it is, has a bit more structure and presence than older games, and even has a fairly satisfying conclusion.  

It's hard to really not recommend MURI. It's a great little one-sitting action platformer that hits all the right notes and doesn't really outstay its welcome, nor does it feel like a chore to play with its slavish emulation of games from a time when technology was a lot more limited.

13103163.review:
One of the better retraux-style games out there, it combines DOS era graphics and gameplay with a more refined, modern style of level design, which really just works. Points for both authenticity (includes 16Hz mode!) and playability.  Best of both worlds.

12783660.review:
MURI is a pretty fun little game. It's short, simple, and to the point. 2D platforming and shooting. This game replicates old DOS games. I never really played anything on DOS when I was younger, but I've played NES games and retroactively played a few select DOS titles. So as long as you're into retro style games, you'll probably enjoy this.

This game controls pretty well. You only have a few functions, but it's pretty easy and smooth... and I even played on the choppy authentic settings. You jump, duck, and shoot your way through the levels collecting items for points. The game is even nice enough to tell you once you've got all the items in an area, so you'll know for sure if you found all the secret spots or not. Also, it's worh mentioning that your jump is actually responsive to how long you hold the jump button and the rate of ascent and descent is the same. It might not sound like much, but it makes the game very easy to control compared to some stiffer titles of the past. Also, you can get a small variet of cool weapons, each one stronger than the last. There are four episodes and five levels per episode, making the game 20 levels long. It took me about two hours to beat the whole thing 100% the first time I played. 

The retro style is done very well in this game. Where some games blend different retro references for nostalgia, MURI really sticks to a fully classic experience. Gameplay, music, sounds, visuals... the works. It's all done in a way that makes you believe it really could be an old DOS game. I love it. The classic feel AND mentality are in tact. 

As much as I enjoyed the game, there are a few issues, as with every game. One of them is that... well... it's short. The content that's there is good so I can't complain too much, but a lot of people will be offput by the brevity. The next two things I'm lumping together and you'll see why. No saving and no switching weapons. Both of these things would be very easy to put in. The thing is... they are a choice. Obviouly a game that came out in 2013 COULD have a button for saving and a button to change weapons, but it doesn't. These choices were made to give meaning to the extra lives and weapons you find. Sure, saving after every level would be convenient, but it would defeat the purpose of getting extra lives by reloading every level if you mess up. Plus, the episodes are pretty short, only took me roughly 30 minutes each and it was my first time playing... got 100% score on them all... you'll have plenty of time to beat an episode and each episode starts you with nothing anyway so it's the same as having a save between episodes really. Switching weapons would make you stock up on ammo to beat tough bosses and enemies rather than conserve your ammo and take careful shots with the guns you acquire. These choices are not only for a retro feel, but they also make sense for the game's difficulty. They're design choices... so I can't be too upset about them.

Overall, it's a pretty fun little game akin to the first two Duke Nukem games. If you like retro style games of the 2D platformer shooter genre, check it out. Is it worth the $6 asking price? $4 isn't too bad. It could be a little cheaper, and you can always wait for a sale, but if you're up for trying out the difficulties and replaying it a few times after you've bought it rather than making it just a one time deal, then it's a fair price. I got it on sale for 40 cents so it was well worth it for me. Maybe wait for it to go on sale if you're skeptical, but just don't forget about it. It's a decent little title without all the frills of achievements to intimidate you along the way. I like it.

To summarize it in one sentence, : "ode to Apogee's early DOS platformers". 
Everything in Muri - from sounds to graphics to gameplay - was crafted to remind you of those games, and fulfills that goal exceptionally.
There's only one real problem: the game is so short it can be completed in less than two hours ( less if you don't run out of lives at some point or aren't going for 100% completion ). 
Don't get me wrong - it's a very pleasant two hours. Unfortunately, once that's over there's no reason to go back - no achievements, no custom levels, no community features such as leaderboards.
If you can get it during a sale or in a bundle, by all means go for it - buying it at full price, though, is something you might want to think twice about.

EDITED: All right, so it turns out I've missed two things: there is one additional secret area with a hint regarding a bonus boss, and the boss itself - not so much difficult to beat as difficult to get to. If you're a completionist, that's an extra 1-2 hours of gameplay on highest difficulty.

12743462.review:
MURI - платформер, стилизованный под старые DOS-игры, в которой рассказывается история из далекого будущего, когда планета Марс была колонизирована, и ее стали использовать как полигон для различных научных исследований. Однако после того, как на планете внезапно прогремел взрыв и исчезло практически все живое, Марс стал похож на выжженую планету, и молодая африканская девушка-ученый по имени Adwoa вызвалась найти остатки человеческой расы и спасти их от верной гибели. 

Стоит сказать, что этот платформер неожиданно хорош. Мало чего ждешь от игры объемом в 3 Мб. Однако, он просто отличный, близкий к идеальному, хотя внешне и выглядит простовато и как-то неотшлифовано. Но вполне может затянуть и заставить игрока (такого, как я, например) поностальгировать по былым временам. Атмосфера угнетенности, всеразрушения и выжженности планеты передана великолепно, мне действительно было интересно узнать, что же там дальше по сюжету и чем все это закончится.  

Рассмотрим плюсы игры: 
+ Отличное управление. Оно действительно очень отзывчивое и "ровное", особенно, при игре на геймпаде. 
+ Увлекательность игрового процесса. Просто не мог оторваться, пока не прошел полностью) 
+ Разнообразные враги и боссы. 
+ Огроооооооомная куча секретов и потайных комнат, некоторые из которых требуют специальной "атлетической" геймерской подготовки) 
+ Хорошо проработанные карты локаций, каждый уровень существенно отличается в визуальном плане. 
+ На жестком диске занимает всего 3 Мб (!!!!!). При этом, на качестве локаций это никак не сказалось.
+ Скрытые персонажи (тайком появляющиеся за пределами экрана), которые добавляют атмосферности игре. 

К сожалению, как и в каждой игре, здесь тоже имеются недочеты, но минусами я бы не стал это называть. 
- Продолжительность игры. 4 уровня по 5 локаций в каждом. Прошел ее за 94 минуты, то бишь 1,5 часа. Это при том, что почти все локации прошел на более, чем 90%, лазил по тайникам и занимался собирательством различных плюшек)) Это значит, что, в принципе, игру можно пройти менее, чем за час. С другой стороны, за это время она не успевает надоесть, так что, наверное, это и не недочет. 
- Возможно, баг. При игре на ноутбуке с геймпадом периодически нужно нажимать клавиши, чтобы монитор не отключался. Почему-то во время игры компьютер думает, что я ничего не делаю и отключает монитор)) Додумался нажать ESC, и понял, в чем дело. Иногда это причиняет неудобства, когда он начинает темнеть в неподходящий момент.  

Как итог - отличный платформер для любителей олдскула, возможно, даже лучшее, что есть в Стиме за такие деньги (на момент написания обзора - скидка в 90%, т.е. купить можно за 0,19$. Я же ее получил через какой-то бандл за сущие копейки, уже запамятовал. Установил, просто для карточек, а затем не удержался и прошел). 
За полную цену брать не советую, она максимум на 2-3 прохождения. Оценю в 8,5/10.

12740067.review:
So you grew up in the '90s, right? Played a lot of Commander Keen, Biomenace, Duke Nukem (the first two) and all sorts of other twodimensional platformers? Or at least you're hip and nerdy enough to honestly appreciate those kind of games?


Well, here's your chance to relive that particular place in time and space with a new adventure! Play MURI for ten seconds and you'll be thrown back immediately (actually you don't even need those ten seconds - just look at the intro screen and listen to the theme music), and ever now and then you get surprised by some more modern contraptions.  

The controls are fine and work perfectly. Don't be put off by the lack of save game or map options, the levels aren't that big and the game isn't that long. You'll manage. The only thing I thing that should have been included is the option for the player to choose their own weapon type instead of automatic assignment. Not exactly sure why the devs choose to do otherwise, but oh well. 

The level design is fun and does the one thing right that so many games do wrong nowadays: you can fully backtrack every part of the level at your own pace and leisure to get all those hidden secrets and goodies. 

The enemies are the most interesting part of this short little hommage to the oldschool platforming era. They're quite original in design and behaviour and they fit the weird SciFi storyline perfectly imho. Can't say much more about it without spoiling it though, you'll need to experience that yourself.


Get this game (especially when it's on sale, at the time of writing it's as low as €0.39)  and enjoy your one or two hours of well executed retro fun. I know for sure I did.

Muri é um prato cheio pra quem é minimamente curioso nos games desenvolvidos para PC durante aquela era obscura (também conhecida como anos 80) na qual os consoles quase acabaram no limbo.

Muri é um side-scroller que imita muito bem os games dos anos 80 desenvolvidos para os PCs da época. E, pra falar a verdade, seria uma puta produção para aqueles anos. Os sons são incríveis, a iluminação é interessantíssima e os gráficos são coloridos e bem trabalhados.

11990726.review: MURI is an old-school PC style action platforming game. It's reminiscent of one of those shareware games you used to play on your Windows 95 IBM PC back in 1997. It's challenging, fun, and well designed with loads of secrets to uncover and hidden areas to explore. MURI also features a dark and surprisingly engaging story told through cutscenes and dialogue. It'll give you some Metroid vibes, but it's not a "Metroidvania" in the usual sense. Shooting, jumping, dodging, and discovering are the name of the game here. It's short, sweet, and begs to be replayed on higher difficulties. MURI is a great game that any fan of retro games should buy immediately.

11547358.review:
Buy? Yes.

MURI is a delightfully DOS-era inspired action platformer. The games play much like the original Duke Nukems. While I've never played them, I've seen footage of them and I have played many DOS games in my childhood, and MURI takes me back.

Contrary to popular belief, not all old games where hard, and MURI is actually quite easy on normal difficulty, almost childishly so due to energy pick up and lives. I recommend a minimum of Hard difficulty to any reasonably seasoned player, though Normal is fine if you're just clearing your backlog...you may not loose any of you live.

MURI gets the old school feel perfectl right down the the graphical style, sound effects, lack of in game music (only the menu....and maybe cutscenes have music, and if you so desire, you can play the game in a reduced frame rate much like the games of the time.

You start with an unlimted ammo single shot blaster, and you can gradually get better weapons with limited ammo like rapid fire, spread shot (MRV), laser, or heat-seeking flares. Occasionally, you can pick up infinite versions of weapons which last the rest of the episode, or at least the level. The goal of the game is to get to the end of the level and you can attempt to get all the point pick-ups and secrets if you desire (and you can actually turn around and get them if you missed them! Take that modern game design!). Each episode ends with a boss.

At the end of the day, MURI doesn't necessarily do anything remarkable - tons of old games have done something like this and games have advanced well beyond the DOS era. But MURI is a newly made game that gets the retro-style gameplay and appearance perfectly and is a no brainer for anybody who enjoyed PC gaming from the late-80s and early 90s.

11443511.review:
I grew up playing side scrollers not on a gaming console, like the NES, but on our old PC. Duke Nukem, Commander Keen, Crystal Caves, all those old, crappy Apogee platformers would be my beck and call for hours on end.
Muri perfectly encapsulates all those games were. From the animations to the music, the sound effects, collectibles, it's all there, wrapped up in a neat storyline that actually breaks from what those old games were about.
If you spent your early years as I did trying to master the strange physics of Duke Nukem's jumps and Halloween Harry (Alien Carnage)'s secret rooms, I strongly recommend you pick up Muri.

11322224.review:
To start: I used to add a header to these reviews, but since it often times made the reviews a bit too long, I've left it on my Backloggery page. Even though I don't think that'll be an issue for this game, I feel compelled to point that out anyways. Besides, it's worked fine so far.

Gameplay: If you've never played a DOS-style shooter before, think something like the original Contra but with more maze-y levels. If you have played a DOS-style shooter, this is pretty much par for the course. The stages are labyrinthean with plenty of secrets; some of which are pretty easy to spot while others require you to dig deeper into the level for something like a switch that activates something at the beginning of the level. I got an average of 95% of the points for each of the levels, with the exception of the boss levels, but that's just because of how the game scores points. There's four episodes which consist of five levels a piece; four stages and a boss stage. Hidden somewhere in the first four stages of each episode are items called cells which allow you to get some extra powerups before the boss of that stage. They're not essential, but they certainly do help.

Bosses in this game are actually really good; certainly a lot better than some of the bosses you'd see in the Commander Keen series. I only played through the game on Normal, but even on that difficulty they were a bit of a handful. The final boss was just plain excellent and a great way to end the game. As for the weapons, you have your standard pea shooter, a rapid shot, a five-way spread, a laser that splits and bounces off of walls, a homing explosive shot, and Chaos which just does things and kills enemies sometimes. 

Apart from that, that's pretty much your lot for this game. It took me just over an hour and a half to beat the game on normal with a fair bit of exploration of the stages, but that's a pretty good length for a DOS-style game. It definitely has replay value, especially with higher difficulties and 100% playthroughs, so if you're into that kind of thing, this game will certainly be worth the $4. It's simple and compact, and there really isn't a thing Id change about it. 10/10.

Story: Unlike a lot of DOS-shooters, this game actually has a pretty good story. It's a bit hard to follow, but it's a fairly high-level Sci-FI storyline about the creation of life. Surprisingly interesting and a not half bad delivery of what could be perceived as a dramatic ending. 8/10.

Graphics: Fortunately, the game doesn't launch in CGA resolution; that would be annoying. Rather, it fullscreened to my native resolution of 1080p without a hassle, so that's all good. As for the art direction, it's quite good, even if the MURI suits look a bit like Robo-Bunnies. Apart from that, the world designs are good, the enemy designs can be absolutely fantastic, with the boss of Stage 3 being the big standout. I can't quite speak for whether or not it rigidly conforms to the EGA palette or not, but it looks DOS-y and it looks good. 5/5.

Sound: This is something that I don't think I've done in the year or so since I started reviewing games (three months since I started publishing Steam reviews): I'm not gonna rate sound. I really can't, since the game itself goes for yet another factor of the DOS design in that there is no music - save for the title track - and all of the sounds are blips. So yeah, it feels a bit weird to do that, but that's what's happening.

Overall scores are: 10/8/5/0; 9.2/10. A very solid little shooter that's well worth the money. I'll definitely play it again in the future.

9695833.review:
Retro parody is more popular than ever, and while the style and trappings of NES and SNES games seem to be the most popular among retro parody developers, the style of the classic IBM MS-DOS games goes largely ignored. Enter MURI, a retro parody game made in the style of classic DOS games around the EGA era (roughly mid 80s to early 90s) complete with 16 colors, 16 frames per second (with an option for 32) and PC-speaker sounds. In other words, a real gem.

The gameplay is very similar to the original Duke Nukem which is similarly episodic with multiple weapons and even has collectibles in the form of floppy disks and joysticks. It's a very fun and refreshing kind of game you don't see anymore, even among indie developers. I found it to be a very enjoyable, albeit brief experience even with four episodes. And lest not forget MURI has a score system which is not found in games of this type anymore, so even if you beat the game there is some replayability if you like getting high scores, especially as there is a multiplier based on chosen difficulty.

Overall a pretty fun game, especially if you're old enough to remember when games came on floppy disks. And it's very low in price too.

9144909.review:
Quello del retrogaming è un mondo sempre più grande, sconfinato se ci si comincia ad appassionare alle correnti più di nicchia. Non vi è dubbio, infatti, che vi siano correnti che tirano più di altre e che negli anni recenti hanno influenzato numerose nuove uscite dal feel vintage: in Europa ci sono stati tributi soprattutto al Commodore 64, negli Stati Uniti c’è stato più amore verso il NES, un po’ ovunque si è pensato al Super Nintendo in caso di RPG. Il PC ha sempre avuto una vita meno facile, perché i suoi vecchi giochi sentono più di altri il peso degli anni, perché non c’è stata mai una potenza commerciale a sostenerne la missione videoludica, ma via via sono stati riconosciuti grossi meriti a DOS e Windows. Gli arcade, però, sono stati spesso territorio di brutte figure: per certe cose il PC non era tagliato, basti pensare ad alcune terrificanti conversioni di coin-op, ma quando gente con sale in zucca ha provato ad esibirsi in questo stesso campo si sono viste cose apprezzabili, come i Duke Nukem bidimensionali o i Commander Keen.

MURI della Remar Games per Ludosity parte proprio da questi esempi e non solo per la struttura da action game, ma addirittura per caratteristiche tecniche al netto di qualche paradosso. I giochi citati giravano alla grande su processori 286 e 386, 16 MHz probabilmente erano anche troppi mentre MURI necessita pur sempre di un Pentium 4, ma almeno il download ricorda veramente i vecchi tempi: soli 3 megabyte, una misura verosimile per quei giochi serviti su floppy disk. 

I PCisti dell’epoca noteranno al boot del gioco subito una cosa riguardante la grafica: è in EGA! L’EGA era l’acronimo di Enhanced Graphic Adapter ed era una delle ragioni dei punzecchiamenti degli amighisti al tempo: la risoluzione video dei giochi era sempre 320x200 pixel, e questo non era un problema, a differenza della palette che mostrava 16 colori da un totale di 64, che non erano tutti selezionabili ma disponibili solo a luminosità diversa. Alla fine, ci si trovava sempre con combinazioni acide, magari utili per lavoro ma orribili per i videogiochi, con dei magenta e verde chiaro che si fissavano in maniera indelebile nelle retine degli utenti. E poi c’era lo scrolling, memorabile per la sua scattosità. Tutto questo è presente in MURI, nel bene e nel male.

Il menu iniziale ci presenta una schermata di presentazione con poche scelte, ma è significativa l’opzione per modificare la fluidità del gioco: disattivandola, lo schermo si muoverà a scatti proprio come accadeva sui PC di fine anni Ottanta, con un effetto che oggi richiede diversi minuti per abituarsi; attivandola, invece, l’impatto sarà meno traumatico pur non ottenendo, volutamente, uno scorrimento perfetto.

Come da tradizione del tempo, all’inizio della partita è possibile scegliere l’episodio da affrontare. Chi ricorda Wolfenstein 3D o Doom capirà, è un retaggio del mercato shareware, dove veniva distribuita gratuitamente una parte di gioco abbastanza consistente, molto più di una demo di oggi, e spesso si trattava appunto di un intero episodio del gioco, mentre gli altri erano disponibili solo per chi comprava il gioco. Ovviamente internet non c’era e le cose funzionavano un po’ diversamente, ma è un’altra storia.
Ogni episodio è diviso in cinque livelli, al termine dei quali non manca neppure un boss da abbattere. MURI inquadra la protagonista omonima lateralmente, proprio come vuole la tradizione dei platform, ed i vari stage presentano un’estensione discreta che si sviluppa in senso verticale ed orizzontale. Al giocatore non vengono mosse richieste particolari: bisogna semplicemente arrivare all’uscita sani e salvi. Lo scenario, però, è ricolmo di oggetti utili per lo score ed alla fine del livello potremo scoprire la nostra percentuale di raccolta. Non mancano passaggi segreti, spesso da aprire sparando, e scovandoli ci permetterà spesso di accedere anche a delle armi. MURI, infatti, è munita di uno sparo di base abbastanza fiacco che rimane tale solitamente per pochi minuti, dato che è diffuso il power-up per il fuoco rapido e non ci vorrà molto per trovare quello ad ampio raggio o altri più speciali e più devastanti. Buona anche la varietà dei nemici, differenziati per comportamento e per colore, il quale ne indica la pericolosità, con i rossi alquanto combattivi e resistenti.
Altre due cose vanno segnalate: la prima riguarda il sonoro, che segue la medesima filosofia della grafica, alimentando la sospensione dell’incredulità temporale af

8725632.review:
MURI is a 2D platformer in the style of old classic DOS platformers like Commander Keen.  As such, the graphics and sound are intentionally limited to fit the restrictions of an old EGA video card with only a PC speaker for audio.  The controls are identical to those of the first few Commander Keen games, with Alt jumping and Ctrl firing, and the arrow keys for movement.

It claims to support gamepads, but wouldn't recognize my Xbox 360 controller.  It may be looking for older DirectInput controllers, but I didn't test that.  Any method you have for mapping controller buttons to keyboard signals should suffice if you want to use a controller but it doesn't recognize yours.

Given the restrictions it's placed on itself, the graphics and sound are very good.  It has a fairly unique visual style, and a font quite reminiscent of classic DOS platformers.

I wholly recommend MURI on two levels.  First, to anyone who enjoys 2D platformers, it's a solid experience.  Second, to anyone who liked classic DOS platformers, it's very similar in graphics, sound, and controls.  Also, if you like this game and want more of the same style, look up the Commander Keen Complete Pack to find the first five games in that series.

8491252.review:
The field of PC platformer nostalgia is a bit of an odd duck. There just weren't that many options in the 16-color EGA era; Apogee and id Games, primarily. Still, the four-directional (if a bit clunky) scrolling and rich diorama-like scenery provided an experience unlike the console platformers of the time.

MURI captures the feeling of that era without its missteps; Daniel Remar puts all his skill at well-designed levels full of secrets and gigantic boss battles here. The player character's slowness and limited set of movements doesn't feel unfair, and the enemies are challenging despite their own constraints.

The game is definitely short, about an hour from start to finish. Like most Remar games, the true replay value is in trying to get the highest score at the highest difficulties, a challenge once again relevant in the Let's Play decade.

8449253.review:
The recent years have seen the rise of "retro"-style games, which seemingly attempt to recreate the look and feel of old games. From this, we've gotten countless NES—er, "8-bit" style games, whether they were created to honestly bring back the feel of an "8-bit" game or just to have an "excuse" to give for horrible artwork. Yet, very few designers have ever done the same with other consoles—or old computers. Daniel Remar (the creator of Iji) adds to this niche with MURI, a side-scrolling platformer which takes after the first Duke Nukem from the DOS shareware era of 1991 but adds and fine-tunes many features to make it its own game. Everything here feels authentic, from the PC speaker sounds to the choppy scrolling (which can be changed to be smooth from the Options menu if you feel like it) to the EGA palette (nothing in the game uses any more than the EGA card's standard 16 colors).

But it's a fun game, too, with movement that feels more fluid than you'd think it'd be and a difficulty balance that feels about right. The levels are of the exploratory kind instead of a linear sort, and it feels great when you find the way to an item that seems just out of reach. It's a rather short game, though, with five levels for each of the four episodes (a touch of the shareware era), even if they get longer as you progress.

Overall, it's a successful return to early 90s DOS and good way to spend ~2 hours of free time. The $3.99 price tag doesn't hurt, either!

8421588.review: Я очень люблю старые игры. Порой слишком старые. На днях вот прошел первого Дюка Нюкема, который совершенно дикий, но тем не менее классный для своих лет. MURI вышла в начале декабря этого (2013) года практически незаметно для всех: статистика никакая, фонов и карточек дефицит. На распродаже игра не получила скидку, но из-за ничтожно малой цены за такую классную идею я все-таки рискнул и приобрел. Не прогадал. Перед нами действительно игра времен DOS, будто её забыли выпустить 25 лет назад и она добралась до нас сейчас, только времена дискет давно прошли, приходится выпускать в стиме. Конечно, игра сильно упрощена: не такой запутанный дизайн уровней (но он просто на высоте, искать всяческие секреты и выход с уровня одно удовольствие), несколько уровней сложностей (что, наверное, к лучшему) и некоторые геймплейные упрощения. Управление осталось классическим - на Alt прыгаем, на Ctrl стреляем, на подобных бережно перенесенных мелочах и держится игра. Еще радует, что до последнего момента игра радует новыми противниками. В итоге перед нами отличная демонстрация того, как "это" было раньше для неспособных или нежелающих погружаться в хардкор былых времен. Рекомендую.

8375363.review:
This is by the guy who did Iji, Hero Core, and Hyper Princess Pitch, so if you liked any of those, you'll probably want this. Specifically, it looks and plays a lot like the original Duke Nukem from 1991, but it has a lot of cool features of its own.If you haven't played the original Duke, you're given about 16 decently sized levels you're free to wander around and explore in, grabbing stuff for points, getting better firepower, and looking around for secrets. 

The game's pretty short, but each episode comes with a boss fight that gets tougher and more interesting the harder the difficulty you play it on. There's also always the drive to improve your score by looking for more of the secrets and getting better times, too, which is cool if you're into score attacking.

Personally, I like this game just for how authentic it is. Nothing in the game uses 16 colors, and even the sound effects come right out of the PC speaker. For some people, it might be a little tough to look at, but for somebody who grew up with DOS, it's a lot of extra effort that I feel makes the game really special. Not many games at all have ever used this kind of style, compared to how many NES-style games are out there, so I really, really appreciate it. Here's hoping for DLC, or better yet, a sequel.

Your objective is to run, jump, and shoot your way to victory through a horde of robots and mutants across 4 episodes. Each episode consists of 4-5 levels and can be completed in roughly 30 minutes if you know what you're doing, even if you search out secrets (of which there are MANY).

MURI is a great little game and is highly recommended to anyone who enjoys platformers with tight controls and lots of combat.

8135341.review:
MURI is a fantastic love letter to EGA DOS games that succeeds not in spite of its 16 color/16 FPS limitations but because of them. Minimalist and spartan it creates atmosphere with empty space, both visually and aurally, and succeeds in crafting a smooth dificulty curve through deliberate level design and the sequential introduction of new challenges and power-ups. The cherry on top is the surprisingly touching story told through tight dialogue scenes that don't overstay their welcome and explore themes of motherhood and sacrifice.

It's a short game, approximately an hour and a half long, but once you start it, it's hard to put it down, and if you have fond memories of shareware and floppy disks its presentation will absolutely satisfy. Game design has matured over the decades and it avoids the pitfalls that its forebears often succumbed to, and I would argue that it succeeds as an engrossing experience even without being viewed through the lens of nostalgia.

8084637.review:
This may be a short game, but it's great all the way through. Four episodes, with four levels (plus a boss level) in each, and I did it in around 2 hours. For the price, though, I'm not going to complain, because it plays very well.

It's EXTREMELY reminiscent of the first Duke Nukem game. Fortunately, I like that game, so I like this too. The main difference with Duke Nukem is the addition of weapons, but other than that, the engine is almost identical (it could almost be a sequel to Duke Nukem, although that already exists). If you take Duke Nukem, mix in some Metroid style, and lowered your character's gravity so you can jump really high, that's this game.

The design is excellent: the weapons are varied, and you can't select them freely so you never feel like relying on any one weapon. On Normal mode, I felt that just as my health was getting low, a health pack would appear, so the levels have been designed well there. I also like the secret rooms to find, and a challenge to get 100% on the level. The addition of cells that open doors to power-ups on the boss level is a nice touch: you can ignore them, but the final battle will be harder, so it keeps you searching.

There are only a couple of negatives I can think of: there is no save function, which is odd for a game like this, but since each episode is done in around 20 minutes, it doesn't really bother me much. Second, I know the graphics and sound are supposed to be like an EGA game with PC speaker, but the music is just a rather dull theme song, then nothing. And the final negative? Not enough levels! It's not entirely a bad thing though, because if they released some more episode packs, I'd definitely buy them too. If you like Duke Nukem 1, get this!

My thoughts on MURI are pretty mixed. It's a fun platformer, but it's so short. I like how a game wouldn't want to over stay it's welcome or anything, but it can be beaten in under an hour. You are never really surprised the whole game. It always plays it safe and never really deviates from the base structure. The game has some level design, but it's all a bit generic. If you are a fan of 90's PC games like Duke Nukem 1 or even Commander Keen and Duke Nukem 2, you should buy this. The games biggest flaw is that it feels too much like a 90's game, you could tell someone it's "The lost Apogee game" and they would believe it, there isn't much replay value (aside from tougher difficulties), and there isn't much variety. There aren't many modern features, I mean, there isn't any coop or anything. The graphics are alright, it looks like I could be running an old DOS game, and is pretty nice by those standards.
Well, overall, I may of sounded a bit disparaging on this, and I may of spent a lot of text talking about MURI's flaws, but it is a fun game which I really enjoyed while it lasted. I'm sure I'll buy the next game the dev makes, the dev has some talent. MURI is not the perfect game, but if you are a platformer fan who has three bucks to spare... Why not give it a shot? 7973136.review:
This game, this game is just so amazing. So many times when you see "retro" style games they are usually either throwbacks to old NES/SNES/Megadrive(Genesis) era games or a lazy excuse for weak graphics since they may look like a old game graphiclly but they don't often play like them. This game on the other hand looks and plays like a old dos era EGA platformer, most notably Duke Nukem 1 so much so I half expected to see the Apogee logo and a shareware registration page which sadly it doesn't have but it does have a quit to DOS option(no seriously, but sadly no Simulated DOS prompt pops up when exiting) and it even uses old PC speaker style sound and music(title screen), so when I say looks and feels like I do mean it, the scrolling is a bit chunky since back in the day smooth scrolling effects were done on the PC through moving 8x8 blocks to simulated smooth movement like arcade and NES games had. 

Only downside it's a bit short since each episode is only 5 levels long and they could tweak the controlls a bit since if your shooting and then push back you don't turn but rather just move back unlike other games from the era it's emulating where you will always face the direction you press shooting or not. Prehapes this is intentional but it's still feels weird at least to me also there are no saves but since each episoded(4 in total) are only 5 levels long it's not a big deal. 

So if you have fond memories of old shareware EGA side-scrollers from the 90's like Duke Nukem, Commander Keen, Bio Menece, Dangerous Dave and the haunted mansion and others then by all means give this a go.

7972508.review:
I bought MURI on a complete whim, going into the game not expecting much. Man, was I wrong. Remar has created something special here and I was nothing to short of being blown away. MURI is a side scrolling run and gun in the guise of an MS DOS aesthetic (seriously, as soon as I saw that DOS style HUD, I knew I was in for a treat) with plenty of things to shoot, plenty of power ups, plenty of levels, a ton of secrets and a phenomenal storyline. MURI is divided into four chapters and does a brilliant job of combining Sci-Fi elements into it's own unique telling, it's simply not enough to explain it here, I alone can do this game no justice. MURI is a special game, that does everything right, the MS DOS feel and aesthetic is beyond perfect, the story is original, the sound effects and what little music there is, is spot on. The game starts off easy, but it really does start getting brutal as it goes on... And theres a hard mode option, if you're feeling brave enough.

MURI gets zero complaints from me, it's an outstanding game that caught me completely off guard, and it's an experience I would happily share with anyone who is interested. To anyone who  is into the DOS scene, to anyone who misses the unique feel of these types of games, you have to try this. Great game, if all my fingers were thumbs, they would be up, but they're not. So it's two thumbs up from me! ;-) well done Remar. Highly recommended!

7959495.review:
MURI is a platforming shooter designed to look and play like old DOS platformers such as Commander Keen or Duke Nukem < 3D. In fact, it's DOS-faithful to a fault, sporting rather loose controls, being less than visually pleasing, and boasting a sound library comprised of mostly farts and silence. However, if hunting for collectable floppy disks and super weapons behind false walls in a robot bunny suit sounds like your idea of a non-productive Saturday afternoon, you can do worse than this game. 
Breaking up the action is a series of incomprehensible story segments with all the narrative finesse of an Iji, or a... you know what, I don't think I've found a video game story quite as ham-handed and inconsequential as Iji's. But MURI's certainly tries, in spite of its greatly reduced length. You may also find some replay value in the more crippling difficulty levels or gunning for the optimal score per level with a system that rewards both complete enemy destruction and minimum time elapsed. Because that's a point of pride among connisseurs of budget-priced, niche-retro-era-styled, other-gratuitously-hypenated-descriptors downloadable games. If you grew up playing this sort of thing on shareware disks or you have a secret-hunting complex, give it a whirl.

7958118.review: This is AWESOME! There are plenty of retro platformers that pay homage to NES and SNES -era games, but not much in the way of DOS Nostalgia.  This platformer is based around finding your way to the exit while trying to collect diskettes, fight enemies, and find secrets. It's very Duke Nukem 1 and Commander Keen 1 in style. If you grew up in that era, you'll probably enjoy this game as well.

7957123.review:
If you've played the early Duke Nukems and Commander Keens you'll immediately feel at home in this game. So far I've finished the first four episodes and they've all been a blast to play. The game not only pays homage to Apogee-style DOS platformers but develops them a bit further. The result is a more rounded game with a lot of secrets and some exciting boss encounters.

Sound
Instead of the PC speaker beepiness (which, admittedly, is faithful to the source material) I'd have preferred an AdLib-type soundtrack.

Graphics
The EGA graphics are fine, even though some of the enemy robots look a bit stiff. Because I played the DOS games I am quite used to the choppy scrolling, thus I haven't tried the smooth mode yet. Maybe I'll try it for the second playthrough.

Gameplay
The game is quite easy on Normal, though on later stages I died several times, in most cases out of carelessness. I imagine the harder difficulty levels are proper challenges. Finding all bonus items in a level provides some motivation to explore the entire level before moving on and later on there are some cleverly placed secrets. The first few stages felt a bit short, but they get more expansive in the later episodes. None of the ones I've played so far have reached the complexity of many Duke Nukem levels, but that is not necessarily a bad thing.

Summary
If you liked Duke Nukem and similar DOS platformer, chances are high you'll love this game as well. It's a short but fun nostalgia trip for a fair price.

Being on semi-slow internet I appreciated the small (3MB) download size. So far the story hasn't blown my mind, but I'll give it a chance, if only just for the fun level design. Weird nostalgia trip back to DOS games. MURI looks very similar to the first Duke Nukem game and plays like these old platformers that had very simplistic and primitive jumping physics. Because it's emulating an old DOS game, it has no music and very simple sounds because games at the time could only use the PC speaker and had one sound channel to work with.

It's a very short game and it's not very difficult but I liked it. It was a nice little nostalgia trip and it's cheap.
